etymologies: late 16th century: modern Latin, from Greek, neuter of skeletos ‘dried up’, from skellein ‘dry up’

definitions: an internal or external framework of bone, cartilage, or other rigid material supporting or containing the body of an animal or plant
shortDefinitions: internal or external framework of bone, cartilage

definitions: used in exaggerated reference to a very thin or emaciated person or animal

examples.text: she was no more than a skeleton at the end

shortDefinitions: used in reference to very thin or emaciated person or animal

definitions: the remaining part of something after its life or usefulness is gone

examples.text: the chapel was stripped to a skeleton of its former self

shortDefinitions: remaining part of something after its life or usefulness is gone

definitions: the supporting framework, basic structure, or essential part of something

examples.text: the concrete skeleton of an unfinished building

shortDefinitions: supporting framework, basic structure, or essential part of something

definitions: denoting the essential or minimum number of people, things, or parts necessary for something

examples.text: there was only a skeleton staff on duty

shortDefinitions: denoting essential or minimum number of people

definitions: a small sled for one person, ridden head first while lying in a prone position

examples.text: the skeleton's runners make a terrifying rumbling sound as they slide down the ice
she can hit 70+ mph on her skeleton sled

definitions: a sport in which a competitor races down a frozen track on a skeleton sled

examples.text: the former heptathlete took up skeleton in 2010

shortDefinitions: sport in which competitor races down frozen track on skeleton
